data.title: Asha Sobhana Joy and the art of finding happiness in the moment by Matchpoint Paradox
data.meta_description:
Asha Sobhana Joy is an individual with immense faith in the universe. In 2021, the leg-spin-bowling all rounder was dropped from the Railways side and found herself low on confidence. She posted a photograph on her Instagram account then with the text — ‘Fall seven times, stand up eight.’

Roughly 869 days later, she and her Royal Challengers Bengaluru outfit, led by Smriti Mandhana, lifted the franchise’s maiden Women’s Premier League (WPL) title. Less than a month later, Asha was named in the squad for India’s five-match T20I series against Bangladesh.

Read the story here
Watch the full chat here
Here's Asha Sobhana's story of how she found cricket and her difficulties staying in the game

Send in your feedback to sportstar@thehindu.co.in

#RCB #wpl2024 #WomensCricket
data.text:
Asha Sobhana Joy is an individual with immense faith in the universe. In 2021, the leg-spin-bowling all rounder was dropped from the Railways side and found herself low on confidence. She posted a photograph on her Instagram account then with the text — ‘Fall seven times, stand up eight.’ Roughly 869 days later, she and her Royal Challengers Bengaluru outfit, led by Smriti Mandhana, lifted the franchise’s maiden Women’s Premier League (WPL) title. Less than a month later, Asha was named in the squad for India’s five-match T20I series against Bangladesh.

Read the story here

Watch the full chat here

Here's Asha Sobhana's story of how she found cricket and her difficulties staying in the game

Send in your feedback to sportstar@thehindu.co.in #RCB #wpl2024 #WomensCricket

From Pakistan's underrated rise this year and Bangladesh's versatile lineup that has given India a run for their money, the Asia Cup is proving to be a crucial practice ground ahead of the ICC ODI World Cup later this year. What do India's opponents look like and what should Rohit Sharma's side watch out for? Dhruva Prasad and VS Aravind explore.

"Who should be India's No. 4" is a debate that raged in the build-up and aftermath of the team's 2019 World Cup campaign. Four years have passed since, but the conundrum continues unabated, with the 2023 World Cup also on the horizon.

India captain Rohit Sharma had recently said that "nobody has come and settled themselves in" for the No. 4 spot. India has tried 11 players at No. 4 in ODIs since the 2019 World Cup, and yet the management, partly due to injuries to key players, seems to be nowhere close to zeroing in on a name.

Sportstar's Ayan Acharya and Dhruva Prasad, wrestle with the subject in this installment of Matchpoint Paradox.

#CricketPodcast #Podcast #IndianCricket #CricketNews

Competitive franchise cricket is no longer a man's world. With the WOMEN'S BIG BASH, the now defunct Kia super league, and the current Hundred putting women's cricket in the spotlight, opportunities for fresh talent to break through and the game to find newer takers are growing by the day. Another addition towards this end is the Women's Caribbean Premier League and the quirky 6ixty tournament currently underway in St Kitts & Nevis.

One element bringing these developments and India closer is Rajasthan Royals CEO, Jake Lush McCrum. The IPL franchise joins Kolkata Knight Riders as the 2nd Indian franchise to dabble in the CPL, going out as Barbados Royals in this ecosystem.

McCrum spoke to Sportstar's Shayan Acharya on prioritizing fan experience, what diving into the proposed Women's IPL seems like, and more.

#RajasthanRoyals #WomensCricket #CricketPodcast

In 1981, India scripted a memorable 138-run victory over England at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai to take a 1-0 lead in the six-Test series.

The team sheet on both sides had legendary names like Sunil Gavaskar, Kapil Dev, Ian Botham, Geoff Boycott, and more. There were no centurions in this Test but the match saw four five-wicket hauls and one of those went to Dilip Doshi when he almost singlehandedly took care of the English lineup which batted second.

In this episode of India's Greatest Cricketing Victories, Sportstar's Vijay Lokapally caught up with the veteran spinner about this match, his playing days, and how far the game has come in India since. Do listen in.

MORE EPISODES:

In this episode of India's Greatest Cricketing Wins, we catch up with veteran offspinner Shivlal Yadav as we revisit a special victory India pulled off over neighbour and fierce rival Pakistan in Mumbai back in 1979.

Vijay Lokapally speaks to the player-turned-administrator about that Test match, the state of spin bowling in India's cricketing ecosystem, why coaching never came up on Yadav's radar, and much more.

Listen in.

In this episode of Matchpoint Paradox, Ayan Acharya is joined by KC Vijaya Kumar, sports editor of The Hindu to discuss the Ranji Trophy final where Madhya Pradesh beat Mumbai. From what this means for the domestic scene, to the standout storyline of MP coach Chandrakant Pandit who fulfilled a long-lasting dream, tune in to this episode for the complete lowdown of the summit clash.

RESOURCES:

Madhya Pradesh wins maiden Ranji Trophy title, beats Mumbai by six wickets in final: https://bit.ly/3a3uBej

Chandrakant Pandit: ‘Felt I had to give something back to MP’: https://bit.ly/3ugEw72

Chandrakant Pandit's commitment, sincerity impacts everybody around: Jagdale - https://bit.ly/3QWAafb

Same ground, different story for Pandit’s Madhya Pradesh: https://bit.ly/3OR5Osz

#RanjiTrophy | #DomesticCricket | #Cricket | #IndianCricket | #CricketNews

For a wicketkeeper, taking six catches in your debut Test match is quite an impressive way to get people to sit up and notice you.

Syed Kirmani has always worn his heart on his sleeve and that's brought him accolades and brickbats in equal measure. He was also an important part of a remarkable win India registered against Australia in 1979 in Bombay where Kirmani scored his maiden Test century

In this installment of India's Greatest Cricketing Wins, the veteran keeper talks about that game, the ups and downs in his career and why talking about his parents always brings tears to his eyes in a candid chat with Sportstar's Vijay Lokapally.

Do listen in.

E01 ft. CD Gopinath: bit.ly/CDGopinath

E02 ft. Farokh Engineer: bit.ly/FarokhEngineer

E03 ft. Karsan Ghavri: bit.ly/KarsanGhavri

The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has reaped a total revenue of ₹48,390 crore through Indian Premier League’s (IPL’s) media rights. At the end of intense bidding over three days through e-auction, BCCI secretary Jay Shah announced the winning bidders on Tuesday.

Star India has bagged the television rights for ₹23,575 crore, while the Viacom 18-led combine has been awarded the digital rights for Indian sub-continent at ₹23,758 crore. The rest of the world rights were divided between Viacom 18 and Times Internet Ltd. for a total figure of ₹1,057 crore.

RESOURCES:

1. IPL second-most valued sporting league in the world in terms of per match value: bit.ly/3mVj6Il

2. IPL media rights: Star India wins TV for Rs 23,575 crore, Viacom gets digital for Rs 23,758 crore: bit.ly/3HtnkAv

#IPL | #Cricket | #Podcast | #CricketPodcast | #IPLTelecast | #IPLRights | #Sports | #SportsPodcast | #SportsNews

The Indian Premier League is not new to astronomical monetary numbers, viewership, interest and crowds. The 15th season which just ended a week ago saw some big bidding amounts and player salaries, massive audiences for games and larger-than-life performances too.

Now, the IPL is turning its attention to another space with scope for big numbers - the media rights auction. This is what we'll dive into in this episode of Matchpoint Paradox.

READ THE STORY HERE: bit.ly/38WrK69

Ft. Amol Karhadkar and Meenakshi Verma Ambwani

#IPL2022 | #IPL | #IPLMediaRights | #IndianCricket | #Cricket | #CricketPodcast | #Podcast

It's one thing to have an achievement like the 1983 World Cup on your resume. But it's a whole other deal to start your career with a match-winning performance against an intimidating and, at the time, world-beating West Indian side at home in your first year in international cricket.

Our guest in this episode has seen it all - the struggles, the rise, the highs, and the obstacles Indian men's cricket has gone through, as a player, coach and selector. In this episode, we catch up with World Cup winner Madan Lal.

E01 ft. CD Gopinath: bit.ly/CDGopinath

E02 ft. Farokh Engineer: bit.ly/FarokhEngineer

E03 ft. Karsan Ghavri: bit.ly/KarsanGhavri

India has some fond memories of playing cricket down under, a few of those are stellar victories too. In this episode, Vijay Lokapally catches up with veteran Indian cricketer Karsan Ghavri about a particularly special victory in Melbourne in 1981 - from his own performance in the game, being received at the airport by Sir Donald Bradman, making Greg Chappell his bunny, and more.

E01 ft. CD Gopinath: bit.ly/CDGopinath

E02 ft. Farokh Engineer: bit.ly/FarokhEngineer

In 1971, India has tamed the British cricket lion in its den. It was a historic day when India beat England in the third and final Test by four wickets with 205 minutes to spare at the Kensington Oval, to clinch the series 1-0. One of the fulcrums of the Indian effort at the Oval was Farokh Engineer. Now 83, the veteran Indian cricketer looks back at that memorable victory with fondness as he joins Vijay Lokapally in this episode.

E01 ft CD Gopinath on India's first ever Test win - bit.ly/CDGopinath

Latest weekly episode - Lowdown on the IPL 2022 Mega Auction - bit.ly/iplauctionlowdown

Report of this match published in The Hindu on August 24, 1971 - bit.ly/3oUHLyt

#CricketPodcast | #Podcast | #Cricket | #IndianCricket | #MatchpointParadox

In this brand new series where we revisit some of India's most cherished cricketing victories, we start at the country's first win in Test cricket history.

We go back 70 years to a historic moment at the MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai where, after 20 years and 24 Test matches, Vijay Hazare captained India to its first win in the format beating England on February 10, 1952.

Coimbatorao Doraikannu Gopinath is the only surviving member of that Indian side and sat down for a freewheeling chat with Ayan Acharya, taking us back in time to his own challenges in making it to the Indian Test team, that memorable win and how Indian cricket itself changed thereafter.

Read the story here: bit.ly/3b61dR9

Watch the interview here: https://youtu.be/mB7Sgke7TiQ

Follow our complete cricket coverage: https://sportstar.thehindu.com/cricket/
